author: By Jenny Gross
title: For King Charles’s Coronation, a Fancy Fish Pie Without the Fish
description: For most coronations over the past 800 years, the city of Gloucester in England has presented newly crowned monarchs with lamprey pies. Charles’s pie was different.
content: GLOUCESTER, England — The coronation of King Charles III and Camilla, the queen consort, on Saturday will involve many of the same ancient traditions that have been followed for nearly a thousand years. But some things will be new: The royal horse-drawn carriage will have air-conditioning. There will be an official coronation emoji issued by Buckingham Palace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Disney Sued by Florida for Control of Theme Park’s Expansion
description: A board appointed by Gov. Ron DeSantis claims the company cut a “back room deal” to control development at Walt Disney World.
content: In the latest chapter of the tussle between Disney and the state of Florida, the newly appointed board for a special tax district encompassing Walt Disney World sued the company in Orlando on Monday to try to regain control over expansion at the theme park complex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Margot, French Fare With a Twist, Opens in Fort Greene, Brooklyn
description: A Spanish wine bar from a veteran of Italian wine, a return to Gramercy Tavern for a highly regarded pastry chef, and more restaurant news.
content: Another refined newcomer is landing in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, stretching the dining options in the neighborhood, a busy cultural hub. At Margot, Three Top Hospitality, a company run by Halley Chambers, Kip Green and Alexia Duchêne, is in charge. Ms. Chambers and Ms. Green met while working for the Oberon Group (Rucola, Rhodora and June) and were introduced to Ms. Duchêne, the French executive chef, through a contact in Paris. Ms. Duchêne presides over a sleek marble counter with eight seats at an open kitchen, where she takes French food and techniques in surprising directions. Her squid “tagliatelle” (Nobu, take note) comes dressed with buttermilk and fava beans. Cavatelli are seasoned with nettles and served with clams, radicchio and brown butter. Pork neck is enriched with green crab butter and a tamarind soubise. She also prepares lamb saddle to share, rolled with market greens and served with lamb belly skewers. Miso fudge and maitake mushroom ice cream are served with some of the desserts. The restaurant’s corner location affords stretches of windows. The interior is spare and light, with bench-like wooden seating, marble-topped tables and that impressive open kitchen. (Opens Thursday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Trump Agrees to Return to CNN, Ending a Long Boycott
description: Since leaving the White House, Donald J. Trump has favored more friendly, right-wing outlets. His decision to appear on CNN represents a shift in his media strategy ahead of the 2024 election.
content: After a long hiatus, former President Donald J. Trump will return to CNN.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Russia’s border region with Ukraine is shelled again, officials say.
description: A village in Russia’s Bryansk region near the border with Ukraine was shelled early Tuesday, the third straight day of security incidents in the area as both sides ramp up fighting ahead of an expected Ukrainian counteroffensive.
content: A village in Russia’s Bryansk region near the border with Ukraine was shelled early Tuesday, the third straight day of security incidents in the area as both sides ramp up fighting ahead of an expected Ukrainian counteroffensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carson Vaughan
title: A ‘Greenwich Village’ on the Prairie
description: When Mari Sandoz, chronicler of frontier life, fled the Sandhills of Nebraska, she found fertile creative ground among the poets and artists of Lincoln. Exploring her world.
content: Were I to write a Mari Sandoz biopic, I’d start with a shadow racing across her desk. I’d start at 3:30 p.m. on Wednesday, Jan. 16, 1935. I’d start with a 39-year-old hayseed — thin as a fence post and prickly as barbed wire — assaulting her typewriter on the ninth floor of the Nebraska State Capitol as a local bank teller plunges 135 feet to his death on the stone transept below. Perhaps I’d cut to the fingernail marks he left on the observation deck five floors above, or the note he left behind. I’d then creep slowly back up to Sandoz, red hair in a French bun, hands on her hips, standing quietly — even knowingly — at the window while her co-workers at the historical society buzz around her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Shein, Fast Fashion Hit With Gen Z, Tries Charm to Counter Scrutiny
description: With an initial public offering expected at some point, the company is looking to change its public perception. Not everyone is buying it.
content: In its decade of doing business, Shein has grown rapidly by winning over shoppers with its tough-to-beat prices and kaleidoscope of new merchandise. Along the way, the e-commerce retailer has also gained vocal critics who have questioned, among other things, its connection to China, accused it of stealing designers’ works and pointed to how its cheap merchandise contributes to environmental waste.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: A Meme That Moves
description: Aimee Lucido’s latest puzzle is here to shake things up.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: How to Feel Less Lonely, According to the Surgeon General
description: America’s top physician, Dr. Vivek Murthy, offers advice on how to build meaningful social connections in an increasingly lonely world.
content: Americans have become increasingly lonely and isolated, and this lack of social connection is having profound effects on our mental and physical health, the surgeon general warned in an advisory on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Thankam Mathews
title: A Black, Queer Hero’s Journey for the Digital Age
description: In Tembe Denton-Hurst’s new novel, “Homebodies,” a young woman loses her New York media job and must figure out how to restart her life.
content: In her sharp, charming and passionate debut, “Homebodies,” Tembe Denton-Hurst showcases an eye for the details that matter. Fashion girls are “Midwest Christian-types born-again in fuzzy pink cardigans and Dries boots.” A girlfriend’s painstaking domestic labors are described with equal parts unease and grateful relief. The impatient lunch-break Slack ping from a peevish white boss perfectly sets up the doom of the meeting that follows. It is this eye for the rhythms and textures of life — of millennial digital media, of the death by a thousand cuts offered by workplace racism, of Maryland suburbia — that makes this novel vivid and inviting. “Homebodies” is the story of a young Black woman’s quarter-life crisis as she wonders what her place in the world will be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Hunter Biden’s Child Support Dispute Touches on Political Discord
description: A legal fight over a request to reduce child support payments has brought up controversies surrounding President Biden’s son, as the mother of his 4-year-old child seeks his financial records.
content: President Biden’s son, Hunter Biden, appeared in an Arkansas courtroom on Monday as part of a bitter dispute with the mother of his 4-year-old child over his request to have his child support payments reduced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ava Sasani
title: 7 Found Dead in Oklahoma Amid Search for Missing Teens
description: The victims were not identified, but the Okmulgee County Sheriff’s Office said the search for the two girls, ages 14 and 16, had been called off.
content: Seven bodies were found on a piece of property in rural Oklahoma on Monday afternoon during a search for two teenage girls who had been reported missing and were said to have been seen with a convicted sex offender, according to officials with the Okmulgee County Sheriff’s Office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: Gordon Lightfoot, Hitmaking Singer-Songwriter, Is Dead at 84
description: His rich baritone voice and songs like “Sundown,” “The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald” and “If You Could Read My Mind” made him a top artist of the 1970s.
content: Gordon Lightfoot, the Canadian folk singer whose rich, plaintive baritone and gift for melodic songwriting made him one of the most popular recording artists of the 1970s, died on Monday night in Toronto. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Mayor Adams Walks a Tightrope in Lashing Out at Migrant Influx
description: Mayor Eric Adams has said the arrival of more than 59,000 asylum seekers has “destroyed” the city, but financial problems loomed before their arrival.
content: Speaking recently to the city’s power brokers at the Real Estate Board of New York’s annual gala, Mayor Eric Adams tried to make the case that his administration had conquered some of the city’s most vexing problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By NE-YO
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Marcos, Back in Arms of U.S., Is Making His Own Name in Foreign Policy
description: In his first months in power, the Philippines leader has reforged a strong alliance with the U.S., winning praise even as questions remain about his path and intent at home.
content: Before becoming president of the Philippines, Ferdinand Marcos Jr. warned that “if you let the U.S. come in, you make China your enemy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Man Dies on Subway After Another Rider Placed Him in a Chokehold
description: The police said the man, 30, was acting erratically on an F train Monday afternoon when another man, 24, placed him in a chokehold.
content: A 30-year-old man who was screaming on a subway train died on Monday afternoon after another rider grabbed him and placed him in a chokehold, according to the police and video of the encounter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Doyle
title: An Illuminating Memoir About Living With Bipolar Disorder
description: “The World at My Back,” by the German writer Thomas Melle, presents the details of his psychotic breakdowns and their painful aftermaths.
content: Living with bipolar disorder — formerly called manic depression — is hard enough, but memoirists afflicted with it face an additional quandary: how to turn their bizarre and frightening experiences into books that grip rather than repel the reader. When they are successful, such reports grant us rare access to the psychic antipodes — a chaotic realm of hyper-signification and cosmic paranoia far beyond the boundaries of healthy consciousness. Joining the likes of Kay Redfield Jamison’s “An Unquiet Mind,” Leonora Carrington’s “Down Below” and, more recently, Arnold Thomas Fanning’s harrowing “Mind on Fire,” is the German novelist and translator Thomas Melle’s illuminating memoir of the illness that has devastated his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: The King Has Definite Ideas About Food. But Will Britain Dig In?
description: A careful eater and a champion of organic farming, King Charles III has a potent pulpit for changing the national diet — though that royal quiche has met some resistance.
content: British supermarkets are brimming with packages of coronation cupcakes, hoppy coronation ale and coronation crisps seasoned to taste like king prawn cocktail. There are even Jack Russell-themed cakes in honor of the king and queen consort’s rescue dogs, Bluebell and Beth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Robert Patrick, Early and Prolific Playwright of Gay Life, Dies at 85
description: He got his start at Caffe Cino, the birthplace of Off Off Broadway. His first of hundreds of plays, performed there in 1964, is a milestone of gay theater.
content: Robert Patrick, a wildly prolific playwright who rendered gay (and straight) life with caustic wit, an open heart and fizzy camp, and whose 1964 play, “The Haunted Host,” became a touchstone of early gay theater, died on April 23 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton and Keith Bradsher
title: In China, It’s Time to Splurge Again, and the Luxury Industry Is Relieved
description: The end of pandemic-era restrictions has unleashed a luxury spending rebound in China. Which Western brands are coming out on top?
content: This time last year, Shanghai — China’s capital of fashion and luxury — was in the throes of a ruthlessly enforced Covid lockdown. The city’s glittering high-end malls and avenues lined with flagship stores stood practically empty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: A Triathlon Champion’s Positive Test Jolts the Sport, Creating a Soap Opera
description: Collin Chartier tested positive for erythropoietin, the well-known illegal stamina enhancer. It came as a shock to devotees of one of the ultimate endurance pursuits, where stamina is everything.
content: For the small, insular world of triathlon, it has been a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin and Brooks Barnes
title: Hollywood Writers Go on Strike, Halting Production
description: The dispute, which pits 11,500 television and screenwriters against the major studios, has shattered 15 years of labor peace in the entertainment business.
content: Hollywood’s 15 years of labor peace was shattered Tuesday, as movie and television writers went on strike, bringing many productions to a halt and dealing a blow to an industry that has been rocked in recent years by the pandemic and sweeping technological shifts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: A second train derailment in two days is reported in a Russian border area.
description: An explosion on Tuesday in Bryansk, along Ukraine’s northern border, sent a locomotive and about 20 train cars off the rails, local authorities said.
content: Local authorities reported on Tuesday that an explosion derailed a freight train in the Russian region of Bryansk, on the border with Ukraine, the second such incident there in two days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Mechanic Charged in Death of Apprentice Crushed in Elevator Plunge
description: The Bronx district attorney said Peter Milatz was criminally negligent in failing to secure the elevator that plunged six stories and killed Joseph Rosa, 25.
content: A mechanic was charged with criminally negligent homicide on Tuesday in the death of an apprentice who was crushed when an elevator car plunged six stories during a maintenance operation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How the Golden Poppy Became California’s State Flower
description: The orange-yellow blooms were adopted 120 years ago as an emblem of the Golden State.
content: There is perhaps no better symbol of California than the glorious, golden poppy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Whang
title: This Robot Can Paint. But Is It Art?
description: Researchers at Carnegie Mellon University developed an A.I.-powered arm that can paint an abstract acrylic. Is it art?
content: One day recently, on a table in Jean Oh’s lab in the Squirrel Hill neighborhood of Pittsburgh, a robot arm was busy at a canvas. Slowly, as if the air were viscous, it dipped a brush into a pool of light gray paint on a palette, swung around and stroked the canvas, leaving an inch-long mark amid a cluster of other brushstrokes. Then it pulled back and paused, as if to assess its work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christie Watson
title: Healing the Unsung Healers
description: In Sarah DiGregorio’s “Taking Care,” the author explores the history, culture and crucial importance of nurses.
content: “Taking Care” is about the meaning of nursing in contemporary America, and its potential to drive change. Written by the journalist — and non-nurse — Sarah DiGregorio, it poses the question: Can nursing be understood from the outside? As someone who was a  nurse for 20 years, I initially thought th answer was “probably not.” I was wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘I Stutter. This Is What You’re Not Hearing.’
description: How can we better understand and fight the stigmas and shame that surround disabilities like stuttering?
content: About three million Americans — or almost 1 percent of the population — speak with a stutter. President Biden has spoken openly about the embarrassment and pain of his severe childhood stutter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Shaw and Julie C. Suk
title: It’s Time to Reacquaint Americans With the Possibility of Changing the Constitution. Here’s Where to Begin.
description: Congress should ratify the Equal Rights Amendment.
content: Last week, the Senate held a vote on the Equal Rights Amendment — the latest development in a century-long effort to amend the Constitution to explicitly guarantee sex equality. The E.R.A. resolution received 51 (bipartisan) votes but fell short of the 60 votes necessary to advance under the Senate’s current rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: For Jodie Comer, ‘this nomination has to mean more than just me.’
description: The actress said she hopes that the play continues to generate discussions around sexual assault and said the response so far has been “beautiful.”
content: That Jodie Comer should have received a nomination for her work in the solo show “Prima Facie,” a role that already won her Olivier and Evening Standard Theater awards, should have come as a surprise to no one. Except apparently Comer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: Markets Sink on Fears About Banks and Weaker Economic Outlook
description: The relative calm that met the collapse of First Republic Bank on Monday was shattered on Tuesday, with broad-based declines across industries.
content: Stocks slumped on Tuesday, as fears about the health of the financial sector after the collapse of First Republic Bank collided with broader anxiety stemming from signs of a weakening economy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Erik Davis
description: The May 2, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Erik Davis. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Australia Aims to ‘Stamp Out’ Vaping With Sweeping Regulations
description: The proposal would ban all single-use, disposable vapes, halt the importation of nonprescription vapes and restrict certain flavors, colors and ingredients.
content: The Australian government said it wanted to crack down on the use of e-cigarettes in an effort to “reduce smoking and stamp out vaping” in one of the most sweeping tobacco regulatory moves in the country in years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: Why Many on Wall Street Fear the Banking Crisis Isn’t Over
description: Even after the sale of First Republic, investors are worried about challenges that regional banks still face, imperiling the economy.
content: After JPMorgan Chase secured a deal to buy the embattled First Republic, the banking giant’s chief, Jamie Dimon, asserted that the market turmoil set off by Silicon Valley Bank’s collapse was at an end. “This part of the crisis is over,” he told analysts on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Muses Upon Muses Inside the Met Gala Cocktail Party
description: Nicole Kidman, Kate Moss, Naomi Campbell and others discuss their roles as muse to Karl Lagerfeld.
content: Nicole Kidman and her husband, Keith Urban, were among the first celebrities to arrive inside the Great Hall at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Monday for the Costume Institute benefit, honoring the designer Karl Lagerfeld. The couple was accompanied by Baz Luhrmann and his wife, Catherine Martin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Minnesota Man Is Charged With Arson After 2 Mosque Fires
description: Representative Ilhan Omar said the man charged with arson, Jackie Rahm Little, had also vandalized her district office in Minneapolis.
content: A Minnesota man was arrested and charged with arson after fires at two Minneapolis mosques last week, federal prosecutors announced on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: What Matters to You in the South?
description: Input from readers will help shape our coverage of the region.
content: Hi — I’m Emily Cochrane, a correspondent for The New York Times. After covering Congress for four years in Washington, D.C., I moved to Nashville to cover the American South. This includes Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Mississippi, Louisiana, both Carolinas and Tennessee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: For Alex Newell, standing ovations just keep coming.
description: Newell was nominated for best featured actor in a musical for their role as the big-voiced whiskey entrepreneur Lulu in “Shucked.”
content: Alex Newell’s Monday night was already pretty great. They attended the Met Gala, landing a spot next to Jimmy Fallon and Glenn Close. “I was like, ‘I’ve made it,’” they said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: The British Coronation: A TV Spectacle, Now for the Digital Age
description: King Charles III’s coronation will be disseminated across numerous platforms to a less sympathetic public than when his mother was crowned in 1953.
content: The mystique around the British royal family — so essential to the nation’s acceptance of its hereditary and privileged first monarchy — has always drawn its power from a blend of secrecy and symbolism that combine in impeccably choreographed spectacle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Root
title: Native Burial Sites Will Soon Be Protected Under Law for the First Time
description: For years, Native American tribes in New York have pushed for greater protections of ancient graves found on private land. Now the Legislature has enacted them.
content: For years, New York law permitted developers to build atop Native American burial sites without taking steps to preserve the ancient remains, making the state one of only four with no meaningful protection for graves on private lands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: James Harden Gives Embiid-less Sixers an Unexpected Win
description: Asked to shoulder the load, Harden scored 45 points in a playoff game for the first time in eight years.
content: The last time James Harden scored 45 points in a playoff game, it was 2015. His Houston Rockets, down three games to none in the Western Conference finals, were winning a home game for pride against the soon to be champion Golden State Warriors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Is the Debt Limit Constitutional? Biden Aides Are Debating It.
description: As the government heads toward a possible default on its debt as soon as next month, officials are entertaining a legal theory that previous administrations ruled out.
content: A standoff between House Republicans and President Biden over raising the nation’s borrowing limit has administration officials debating what to do if the government runs out of cash to pay its bills, including one option that previous administrations had deemed unthinkable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mireille Silcoff
title: How Gwyneth Paltrow Put Concussions On Trial
description: The case against her was weak enough. Did her defense have to mock the very idea of invisible injuries?
content: In March, on Day 7 of the Gwyneth Paltrow ski trial, after the court spectacle had already been branded everything from a “meme machine” to “the whitest trial of all time,” the retired optometrist Terry Sanderson sat in the witness box, somewhat deflated already. By that point, he probably knew that his pursuit of Paltrow for damages connected to a ski collision he said was her fault was a pretty bad idea. Sanderson claimed that injuries he sustained during the 2016 ski crash (including, notably, a concussion) changed his life, turning him into “a different person,” and “a crippled vet.” Paltrow’s lawyer, the languid, unflappably stone-eyed Stephen Owens, stood before him, presenting Facebook posts — a lot of Facebook posts, some taken months after the collision — as evidence of robust health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Generative A.I. Start-Up Cohere Valued at About $2 Billion in Funding Round
description: Founded by ex-Google researchers, the Toronto company is among the few start-ups prepared to compete with the creator of ChatGPT.
content: Cohere, a Toronto artificial intelligence start-up, has raised $250 million in new funding, two people with knowledge of the situation said, in yet another sign of feverish interest in a new kind of A.I. technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: This Little Book of Poetry Made History
description: Phillis Wheatley wrote what is said to be the first book in English by a person of African descent. Bonhams is selling a first edition this week.
content: Good morning. We’ll look at the history and the mystery behind a book that’s being sold in New York. We’ll also find out why a new hospital in Brooklyn is like a fort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: In Berkeley, a Library Protest Is a Fight for Anthropology in an A.I. Age
description: Students are staging an open-ended occupation of the anthropology library after the University of California, Berkeley, announced it would shutter the 67-year-old institution to save money.
content: BERKELEY, Calif. — To kick off homecoming weekend last fall, the University of California, Berkeley, held a groundbreaking ceremony for its new data sciences building, known as the Gateway. At a cost of over half a billion dollars, the 367,270-square-foot building, with “extended sightlines and natural light-filled corridors,” is being billed as a hub for research in artificial intelligence, data analytics and machine learning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Writers Go on Strike and Late Shows Go Dark
description: How long they stay off the air is an open question. During the last strike, they gradually returned after a couple of months.
content: Just hours after the union representing thousands of television and movie writers announced that they were going on strike, hundreds of their members occupied an entire city block in Midtown Manhattan on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Some Like It Hot’ scored the most nods as nominators showered attention on a wide variety of shows and performers.
description: As Broadway’s rebound from the pandemic shutdown picks up pace, Tony nominators showered much-sought attention on a wide variety of shows, from razzle-dazzle spectacles to quirky adventurous fare.
content: As Broadway’s rebound from the pandemic shutdown picks up pace, Tony nominators showered much-sought attention on a wide variety of shows, from razzle-dazzle spectacles to quirky adventurous fare.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A.I. to Read Your Mind Is Up Next
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, May 2, 2023.
content: “Brain activity is a kind of encrypted signal, and language models provide ways to decipher it.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Moogs and Muppets: Record Shopping in Brooklyn
description: Picking through the bins at the Academy Records Annex, and rediscovering “Switched-On Rock,” as well as albums by Tim Hardin and Otis Redding.
content: It’s time for another installment of the recurring Amplifier segment My Record Haul, honoring the serendipity and bargains that can be found at brick-and-mortar shops. Today’s features weird and wonderful finds from one of my favorite places in Brooklyn, the Academy Records Annex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: How Do You Hold It Together When You’re Feeling Stressed?
description: What do you do when life gets overwhelming?
content: Stressed out? Feeling frazzled? Can’t take it anymore?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor and Christopher Mele
title: As attacks on journalists rise, The Times’s publisher warns of risks to democracy.
description: The free press’s role in supporting human rights and democratic societies is “at great risk” amid increasing levels of violence against journalists worldwide, A.G. Sulzberger said.
content: A.G. Sulzberger, the publisher of The New York Times, warned on Tuesday that “when the free press erodes, democratic erosion almost always follows,” delivering a call to protect journalists as fatal attacks on reporters have increased — especially in the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 2, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, May 2, 2023.
content: An article on April 23 about donations from the Sackler family to the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine referred imprecisely to statistics from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on the number of adults in the United States with chronic pain. Roughly 52 million adults suffered from chronic pain, according to a C.D.C. report, and of those, more than 17 million U.S. adults experience high-impact or more severe chronic pain; the number of U.S. adults affected by chronic pain does not range between 17 million and 52 million people. The error was repeated in a follow-up article on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: For Audra McDonald, ‘the work is the true joy.’
description: With “Ohio State Murders,” the 10-time Tony nominee hopes people took away a better understanding of the destructive power of racism.
content: Audra McDonald has been here before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: I Love You, Here’s Some Blood
description: The enduring eroticism of our vital fluids, onscreen and in real life.
content: This article contains details about Episodes 5 and 6 of the final season of “Succession.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden to Send 1,500 Active-Duty Troops to the Southern Border
description: The easing of Covid-era restrictions could lead to an increase in migrants, officials say.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden is sending 1,500 active-duty troops to the southern U.S. border with Mexico, officials said on Tuesday, as the administration braces for a possible influx of migrants seeking to take advantage of the lifting of Covid-era restrictions on asylum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Florida Legislature Moves to Shield DeSantis’s Travel Records
description: The law includes a sweeping retroactive clause that would block the release of many records of trips already taken.
content: The Florida Legislature passed a bill on Tuesday that would shield the travel records of Gov. Ron DeSantis and other top elected officials from public view, a significant change to the state’s vaunted sunshine laws as Mr. DeSantis explores a potential presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Barbara
title: My Country Is Reaching Out to People the West Can’t Stand
description: Under President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, Brazil is charting its own course.
content: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Under Jair Bolsonaro, Brazil was an international pariah. Not my words, but those of the former foreign minister: Apparently it was “good to be an outcast.” I do not miss these people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Prominent Retired Judge Calls for Ethics Rules for Supreme Court Justices
description: In written testimony sent to the Senate Judiciary Committee, the retired conservative judge J. Michael Luttig called for new ethics rules for Supreme Court justices.
content: WASHINGTON — A prominent conservative former federal judge joined a group of legal experts on Tuesday in calling on Congress to enact new ethical standards for Supreme Court justices, after a series of revelations about the justices’ undisclosed gifts, luxury travel and property deals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: House Democrats Move to Force a Debt-Limit Increase as Default Date Looms
description: House Democratic leaders who have been quietly planning a strategy to force a debt ceiling increase to avert default began taking steps on Tuesday to deploy their secret weapon.
content: The only clue to the gambit was in the title of the otherwise obscure hodgepodge of a bill: “The Breaking the Gridlock Act.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Mike Shannon, a St. Louis Cardinal for Life, Dies at 83
description: A St. Louis native, he devoted his entire career to the team — first as an outfielder and third baseman and then, for 50 years, as a radio announcer.
content: Mike Shannon, who played in three World Series with the St. Louis Cardinals and then became a favorite of the team’s fans as one of its radio broadcasters for 50 seasons, died on Saturday. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiana Reid
title: A New Survey Erases Male Artists From the Western Canon
description: Katy Hessel’s “The Story of Art Without Men” is a compendium of female artists from the 1500s to today.
content: “Men put me down as the best woman painter,” Georgia O’Keeffe once said. “I think I’m one of the best painters.” That famous quote by the American modernist serves as an epigraph in Part 2 of the Guardian columnist Katy Hessel’s sweeping first book, “The Story of Art Without Men.” “Women artists are not a trend,” Hessel maintains; and yet the contested category persists, not as a meaningful distinction but rather as a repercussion of patriarchy, a category that the male-dominated art world consistently, in O’Keeffe’s terms, diminishes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: After Pandemic Rebound, U.S. Manufacturing Droops
description: Factories that roared out of the recession have stalled, hampering the economy, even as a new wave of production looms.
content: The pandemic had a bright silver lining for Elkhart, Ind.
source.name: The New York Times

title: E. Jean Carroll v. Donald Trump
description: Readers discuss her claim that she was raped by the former president. Also: Teachers and lifelong learning; Indigenous values and a forest.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Everything You Need to Know About the Debt Ceiling
description: Congress controls how much money the United States can borrow. Here’s a look at why that is and what it means.
content: Washington is heading for another big fight over whether to raise or suspend the nation’s debt limit, which caps the amount of money the federal government can borrow to pay its bills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Stewart
title: Where the Milkshakes Are Served With a Celebration of Black Culture
description: At Harlem Shake, which continues to expand, the fun retro vibes connect to a deeper diner history.
content: On a corner in Central Harlem, just blocks from the Apollo Theater and Marcus Garvey Park, stands Harlem Shake, a diner designed to look as though it’s been there for decades. The walls are covered with Jet magazine covers and photographs, some signed, of Black American musicians and celebrities: Regina Hall, Diddy, Maya Angelou, Questlove. Its retro diner-style menus and swivel bar stools evoke nostalgia for an era of charm — and upheaval — in American culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: What to Know About Hunger Strikes
description: The actions are almost always political, and governments sometimes resort to force-feeding, a practice denounced as inhumane. Deaths like that of a Palestinian prisoner this week are uncommon.
content: The death this week of a Palestinian prisoner, Khader Adnan, who starved himself in Israel to protest his detention, threw a spotlight on a method of nonviolent resistance, part of a history of protest that turns the captive’s body into a tool to achieve change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant and Steven Lee Myers
title: Google Promised to Defund Climate Lies, but the Ads Keep Coming
description: Google said in 2021 that it would stop running ads alongside videos and other content that denied the existence and causes of climate change.
content: In October 2021, Google promised to stop placing ads alongside content that denied the existence and causes of climate change, so that purveyors of the false claims could no longer make money on its platforms, including YouTube.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Greenblatt
title: How Did ‘Beau Is Afraid’ Land a Mariah Carey Song? Indies Have Their Ways.
description: A well-written letter and other methods of persuasion can help reduce the cost of expensive hits and produce unforgettable results.
content: Beau, the addled midlife wreck played by Joaquin Phoenix in “Beau Is Afraid,” isn’t just afraid, he is terrorized: harassed, beaten, stabbed and even kidnapped in a surreal black comedy that often feels less like a conventional film than a three-hour panic attack. (In the hands of high-anxiety auteur Ari Aster, of “Hereditary” and “Midsommar” fame, consider that a compliment.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: Trump Likely to Sit Out One or Both of First Two G.O.P. Debates
description: In private comments to aides and confidants, Donald J. Trump has indicated he does not want to breathe life into his Republican challengers by sharing a debate stage with them.
content: The leading Republican candidate for president, Donald J. Trump, is likely to skip at least one of the first two debates of the 2024 Republican presidential nominating contest, according to five people who have discussed the matter with the former president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Judge Rejects Montana Lawmaker’s Effort to Return to House Floor
description: Representative Zooey Zephyr sued after being barred from the chamber in a standoff that started over her comments on transgender legislation.
content: A judge ruled on Tuesday against a Montana legislator who had sought a court order allowing her to return to the House of Representatives after she was barred during an escalating standoff over her remarks on transgender issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Rent for Millions of New Yorkers Could Increase by 2 to 5 Percent
description: The panel, known as the Rent Guidelines Board, took a preliminary vote on potential rent hikes on Tuesday evening.
content: The New York City panel charged with regulating rents across nearly one million rent-stabilized apartments gave preliminary approval on Tuesday to some of the largest increases in years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: The Shed Plans to Bring a Modernist Dream to Life
description: A spherical concert hall inspired by the composer Karlheinz Stockhausen’s ideas will be suspended in the Shed’s McCourt space.
content: At the height of musical modernism, the composer Karlheinz Stockhausen conceived a spherical concert hall — the Kugelauditorium — that would surround its audience with dozens of meticulously arranged speakers for an entirely new kind of listening experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: In Trump Trial, a Lawyer Pushes, and E. Jean Carroll Pushes Right Back
description: The writer E. Jean Carroll and Donald Trump’s lawyer, Joseph Tacopina, clashed repeatedly over her account of how she reacted after she was attacked.
content: Even the greeting was tense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: 17 Looks That Did the Most at the Met Gala
description: Who interpreted (or ignored) the Karl Lagerfeld theme best? Hint: Doja Cat, Lil Nas X, Phoebe Bridgers, Jared Leto and Anok Yai made the list.
content: The guest list for the first Monday in May, as the Met Gala is also known, serves as a Rorschach test for whom Anna Wintour deems important, circa now. This year’s attendees included many of the frequent fliers, like Kim Kardashian, Gigi Hadid and Serena Williams, as well as some new names: the W.N.B.A. star and recent Russian detainee Brittney Griner, the musical artist Doja Cat and — shockingly — Paris Hilton. (How is it possible that she’s never gone before? A grotesque oversight!)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Russia Ramps Up Pressure on Civilians in Occupied Ukraine
description: Wary of Ukrainian partisans and anticipating a counteroffensive, Russian authorities have “reinforced” counterintelligence units in occupied territory, Ukraine says.
content: Russia is ramping up pressure on civilians in occupied parts of Ukraine, according to Ukrainian officials, whose forces have stepped up their assaults behind enemy lines ahead of a widely expected counteroffensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Dancin’’ to Close on Broadway, a Casualty of Tony Nominations
description: The production, a revue celebrating the choreography of Bob Fosse, received no Tony nominations on Tuesday. Its last show will be May 14.
content: This season’s Broadway revival of “Dancin’,” a revue celebrating the choreography of Bob Fosse, will end its short run on Sunday, May 14, the show’s producers announced on Tuesday evening, just hours after receiving zero Tony nominations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Palestinian Detainee Dies in Israeli Prison After Hunger Strike
description: Khader Adnan had led a hunger-strike movement among Palestinians to protest detentions. Palestinian leaders and armed groups blamed Israel for his death, and claimed responsibility for a rocket strike in response.
content: Khader Adnan, a prominent Palestinian prisoner who had been on a hunger strike in an Israeli prison for 87 days to protest his detention, died early Tuesday, according to his lawyer and Palestinian and Israeli officials, amid rising violence in the occupied West Bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele and Andrea Kannapell
title: At a U.N. event on press freedom, the publisher of The New York Times warns of dangers to democracy.
description: A.G. Sulzberger, the publisher of The New York Times, warned on Tuesday that “when the free press erodes, democratic erosion almost always follows.”
content: A.G. Sulzberger, the publisher of The New York Times, warned on Tuesday that “when the free press erodes, democratic erosion almost always follows.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek, Benjamin Weiser and Lola Fadulu
title: Carroll’s Friend Tells of a Fraught Call Reporting an Attack by Trump
description: E. Jean Carroll, who has accused the former president of raping her, has finished her cross-examination. On Tuesday, her lawyers called witnesses to bolster her case.
content: During her testimony in the civil trial against former President Donald J. Trump, E. Jean Carroll told the jury that she had called a friend immediately after leaving the department store where she said he had raped her in the mid-1990s. On Tuesday, that friend took the witness stand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Ex-Officer Guilty of Abetting Manslaughter in George Floyd’s Killing
description: A judge in Minneapolis ruled that the former officer, Tou Thao, was guilty of aiding and abetting manslaughter in the killing of Mr. Floyd in 2020.
content: A former Minneapolis police officer who held back bystanders as other officers restrained George Floyd was found guilty on Monday of aiding and abetting second-degree manslaughter in Mr. Floyd’s killing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Mother and Three Children Among 7 Found Dead in Oklahoma, Relative Says
description: A search for two missing teenagers in a rural town led to a grim discovery at the ranch of a registered sex offender who is believed to also be among the dead.
content: Janette Mayo drove two hours to attend a choir recital last Thursday at a middle school in rural Oklahoma. Her granddaughter Tiffany Dore Guess wore a black and gold robe and sang beautifully, Ms. Mayo recalled.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Crying in the Driveway’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Our children met while teaching in Germany. His son is British; my daughter is American. He and I are both single parents, retired teachers and cheeky devils. Our children fell in love, got pregnant and married — all during Covid, so they had a Zoom wedding and baby shower. Meaning he and I became friends on WhatsApp and Signal before we finally met in person in England. I am more fond of the royals than he is (he thinks they are outdated, parasites on taxpayers). Still, we are kindred spirits, now with actual kin in common. Cheerio, y’all. — Felicia Carparelli
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: The sale of First Republic Bank.
content: In the early hours of Monday morning, U.S. government officials seized First Republic Bank and then sold it to the country’s biggest bank, JPMorgan Chase. Their action appears, for now, to have quelled nearly two months of turmoil in the banking sector that followed the sudden collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank in early March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKenna Oxenden
title: Pornhub Blocks Utah Users From Its Site to Protest Age-Verification Law
description: The law seeks to protect minors from pornography, but the company said that “until a real solution is offered” to verify users’ ages, the website will be inaccessible in the state.
content: The pornography website Pornhub blocked all internet users in Utah from accessing the explicit content on its pages in protest of an age-verification law that requires providing identification and was set to go into effect on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: Discreetly, Berlin Confronts Russian Spies Hiding in Plain Sight
description: For years, Germany seemed to tolerate even flagrant Russian operations on its soil. But a new Cold War-like chill has now made the snooping difficult to ignore.
content: BERLIN — Every day as he settles in at his desk, Erhard Grundl, a German lawmaker, looks outside his office window into the embassy he knows may be spying on him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Grace Lee
title: Doja Cat Made a Fashionably Feline Met Gala Debut
description: One could say she led the evening’s purr-ade of Choupette-inspired looks.
content: While the real Choupette stayed home for the Met Gala on Monday, the stars came out in full feline force to make up for her absence. Jared Leto went furry (and slightly terrifying) in a cat suit and Lil Nas X meowed at the press in glittery, full-body crystal makeup and pearly whiskers. For her first Met Gala, the musician Doja Cat went a slightly more understated route, with a high fashion, anthropomorphic cat look that married beauty, camp and glam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Tannenbaum
title: Lauren Daigle, a Christian Music Superstar, Is Ready for a Bigger Tent
description: The 31-year-old singer and songwriter is releasing a self-titled album on a major label — and bracing for the potential backlash.
content: “I’m terrified,” Lauren Daigle said with a broad smile rather than any evident terror. It was six weeks before the release of her new self-titled album, and the biggest singer in contemporary Christian music (CCM) was sitting in a lounge at the midtown Manhattan offices of Atlantic Records, glowing with positivity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Job Openings Slipped in March as Labor Market Continued Cooling
description: The ratio of open jobs to available unemployed workers fell to the lowest level since October 2021.
content: Job openings in March fell to 9.6 million, the Labor Department reported on Tuesday, the lowest level in two years and a further indication that the slowdown in the labor market is becoming more entrenched. It was the third straight month that job openings have declined, a notable development after last year, when job openings bounced around month to month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Who Will Have the Last Word on the Universe?
description: Modern science suggests that we and all our achievements and memories are destined to vanish like a dream. Is that sad or good?
content: The End is coming, in maybe 100 billion years. Is it too soon to start freaking out?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Eurozone Inflation Rises as Policymakers Weigh a Rate Increase
description: The annual rate of inflation reached 7 percent, but the underlying “core” rate eased for the first time in 10 months.
content: The eurozone’s overall rate of inflation ticked up in April, with the cost of food remaining high. But there was a bit of good news: After subtracting prices for food and energy, which tend to be volatile, the underlying inflation rate eased for the first time in 10 months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Why the 14th Amendment Is Being Cited in the Debt Ceiling Debate
description: Some Biden administration officials believe a constitutional clause prevents the United States from failing to make payments even if it means breaching the debt limit.
content: WASHINGTON — Faced with an impasse over raising or suspending the nation’s debt limit, some White House officials are looking to a clause in the 14th Amendment to ensure the United States does not default on its debt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Two Gender Nonconforming Performers Earn Tony Nominations
description: J. Harrison Ghee of “Some Like It Hot” was nominated in the best leading actor in a musical category, and Alex Newell of “Shucked” was nominated in the best featured actor in a musical category.
content: Even as gender identity has become an increasingly politicized subject in a polarized America, Broadway shows are featuring a growing number of gender nonconforming performers, and two of them scored Tony nods Tuesday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Another Bank Failure
description: Are we on the brink of a financial crisis — or has the threat been contained?
content: The recent fall of major banks — including First Republic Bank yesterday — has caused concerns that the U.S. is on the brink of a financial catastrophe, one that could resemble the 2007-8 crisis that led to the Great Recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Ideas, and Coffee, Robust Enough for the Climate Crisis
description: On a recent reporting trip, your Climate Forward host met small farmers adapting to climate hazards in all kinds of creative ways.
content: As a climate journalist, I get asked a perennial question by my fellow Americans: What do I do in the face of a crisis so big and complicated?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Cusk
title: Annie Ernaux Has Broken Every Taboo of What Women Are Allowed to Write
description: The novelist Rachel Cusk on what makes the Nobel laureate’s fiction so shocking.
content: Perhaps with no clearer motive than F. Scott Fitzgerald’s observation that “France has the only two things toward which we drift as we grow older — intelligence and good manners,” we packed up our possessions during the last dark days of one December and decided to move to Paris. It was pleasant, I had often been told, for a writer to live somewhere where reading and writing were accorded the highest respect, and it was true that — in Paris at least — these were semipublic activities: In every park and cafe, on the Metro and on the benches along the Seine, people were openly engaged in what for me had always been the most private and solitary of occupations. Bookstores still held their ground here among the shopfronts, and the deification of French writers living and dead was evinced everywhere in street names and statues and advertising hoardings for new novels. I listened on the radio to an astronaut reading passages aloud from Marguerite Duras from his space station to his earthbound audience below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Heller and Alexis Soloski
title: Tony Surprises, Snubs and a Watershed Moment That Wasn’t
description: Tony nominators singled out new faces and set up fascinating face-offs, but missed the chance to recognize a Native American breakthrough.
content: Not everyone can wake up to good news on Tony nominations morning. Then again, with a panel of voters often un-wowed by celebrity, the roster typically turns up left-field choices and anoints young talent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Lowenstein
title: How Warren Buffett Came to Refuse Progressive Orthodoxy
description: The billionaire is socially conscious. But he is dismissive of social governance warriors seeking to hijack the corporate mission.
content: Warren Buffett has long been known as a liberal executive. The Omaha billionaire has contributed millions to pro-choice organizations, he has raised money for Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton and he often calls for higher taxes on the wealthy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What Would Karl Have Thought of It All?
description: Karl Lagerfeld was famous for not holding back. So what would he have said about the looks worn in his (and his cat’s) honor?
content: What would Karl have thought? Watching the stream of Lagerfeld-a-likes mount the steps of the Met Monday night in their black and white, it was hard not to wonder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justices Wrestled With Court’s Power in Landmark Abortion Case, Papers Show
description: Justice John Paul Stevens’s files on thousands of cases, including landmark decisions on abortion and the 2000 election, have been made public, opening a window on the Supreme Court.
content: WASHINGTON — In June 1992, less than two weeks before the Supreme Court reaffirmed the constitutional right to abortion established in Roe v. Wade, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy sent a colleague some “late-night musings.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Jay Inslee Sees Greener Pastures Ahead
description: After nearly 30 years in elected office, Washington’s governor plans to shift his focus to climate solutions and clean energy, underscoring the need for “a sense of optimism and confidence.”
content: Jay Inslee has been in elected office so long that he served in Congress during the tail end of the George H.W. Bush administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: The Restaurant Recipes We Just Have to Have
description: Some dishes are so good that you simply must recreate them at home.
content: We’ve all heard it before: Why go to a restaurant to eat something you can make at home? But sometimes you order something so incredible, so unforgettable, that you immediately want the recipe to make whenever you feel like it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun and Jean Chung
title: A Brutal Sex Trade Built for American Soldiers
description: It’s a long-buried part of South Korean history: women compelled by force, trickery or desperation into prostitution, with the complicity of their own leaders.
content: DONGDUCHEON, South Korea — When Cho Soon-ok was 17 in 1977, three men kidnapped and sold her to a pimp in Dongducheon, a town north of Seoul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: A Deep Look at Korean Comfort Women
description: Also, Australia’s vape crackdown.
content: The euphemism “comfort women” typically describes South Korean women who were forced into sexual slavery by the Japanese during World War II. But long after Japan’s colonial rule ended, the sexual exploitation continued with Korean and American soldiers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Uber’s Revenue Up 29% as U.S. Ride-Hailing Business Improves
description: The company said its financial results in the most recent quarter were about in line with the expectations of investors.
content: Uber said on Tuesday that its revenue grew 29 percent in its most recent quarter as the company benefited from a series of investments in new services, as well as the continued return of drivers to its ride-hailing business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: How ‘The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald’ Defied Top 40 Logic
description: Gordon Lightfoot’s 1976 folk ballad told the true story of a shipwreck on Lake Superior. One of his old friends called it “a documentarian’s song.”
content: Gordon Lightfoot, the Canadian folk singer who died on Monday at 84, had one hit in particular that famously defied Top 40 logic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kalia Richardson
title: For Helen Park, ‘KPOP’ nod ‘feels like an encouragement to continue.’
description: Park, the first Asian American female composer on Broadway, was nominated for best original score.
content: Helen Park was tucked in bed in her New Jersey home when her talent agent texted her news of her Tony Award nomination. Park, the first Asian American female composer on Broadway, was nominated in the best score category for the Korean- and English-language musical “KPOP,” which follows three K-pop acts challenged by strict routines and personal struggles as they prepare for a U.S. concert tour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: A Debt Limit Secret Weapon
description: Also, the fallout from the Hollywood writers’ strike and this year’s Tony nominations. Here’s what you need to know at the end of Tuesday.
content: With the U.S. now projected to run out of money to pay its bills by June 1, Democrats in Washington are considering unconventional tactics to avert a devastating federal default.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: One Dose of HPV Vaccine Prevents Infection for at Least Three Years
description: Protection may last even longer, scientists reported. The finding may be a boon to low-income countries, where cervical cancer takes an enormous toll.
content: A single dose of the human papillomavirus vaccine is highly effective at preventing infections over three years, most likely lowering rates of cervical cancer and other diseases linked to the virus, according to a new study in Kenya.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Sudan’s Warring Generals Agree to Weeklong Truce, Says South Sudan
description: The battle has sent 100,000 refugees fleeing across borders. Now, neighboring South Sudan says both sides have agreed to name representatives to peace talks, but neither side has publicly confirmed.
content: The two rival generals fighting in Sudan agreed to a seven-day truce starting on Thursday and will name representatives to peace talks, according to the foreign ministry of South Sudan, which has been working with other neighboring countries to negotiate an end to a conflict that has sent more than 100,000 refugees pouring across their borders in a few weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Serena Williams Wanted Another Baby. At the Met Gala, She Said She’s Pregnant.
description: Williams said last year that she was stepping back from competing on the women’s tennis tour because she wanted to grow her family.
content: Serena Williams has resisted saying publicly that she has retired from tennis and the finality that would bring, but now she has another reason to stay away from competition in the near future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: CNBC Anchor Complained NBCUniversal C.E.O. Pressured Her for Years
description: Hadley Gamble, an anchor and senior international correspondent at CNBC, said in her complaint that former NBCUniversal C.E.O., Jeff Shell, used his position of power to pursue her and pressure her for sex.
content: A CNBC journalist accused Jeff Shell, the former chief executive of NBCUniversal, of pressuring her for sex over a period of years during her career at the business news network, according to a copy of her complaint reviewed by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: shrewd
description: This word has appeared in 117 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word shrewd has appeared in 117 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 31 in “The ChatGPT King Isn’t Worried, but He Knows You Might Be” by Cade Metz:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: What’s Driving Dollar Doomsaying?
description: Send in the cranks — but also some people I expected to know better.
content: Talk of “de-dollarization” and its dire consequences for the U.S. economy seems to be all over the place lately. Somehow, my previous efforts to dampen the frenzy haven’t worked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: In Texas, Aimless Gunfire Rattles Residents, but It’s Hard to Stop
description: The shooting deaths of five people in a rural area northeast of Houston has raised questions about how to handle reports of gunfire in the state, where gun ownership has become less regulated.
content: CLEVELAND, Texas — The sound of gunfire — whether from hunting, or target practice, or celebration — is common in much of rural America. Perhaps nowhere is this more true than in Texas, where the occasional volley rarely raises alarm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: Man Arrested Outside Buckingham Palace as Police Conduct Controlled Explosion
description: Ahead of King Charles III’s coronation, a man threw what police called suspected shotgun cartridges onto the palace grounds, and a bag he carried was detonated as a precaution.
content: The British police conducted a controlled explosion outside Buckingham Palace on Tuesday, detonating a bag taken from a man who they said had thrown suspected shotgun cartridges onto palace grounds just days ahead of King Charles III’s coronation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘King Charles, the Boy Who Walked Alone’ Review: Reflections on a Monarch
description: A sort of cinematic advance man for this week’s coronation, the documentary makes a show of seeking balance but often tips its hand in favor of Charles.
content: Several times in this picture its interviewees attempt to contradict the impression that King Charles is an “old dry stick.” Hence the documentary, directed by Jim Nally, is juicier than its sad-sack title indicates. The “boy who walked alone” phrase comes from Johnny Stonborough, who was a schoolmate of the then Prince of Wales at Gordonstoun, a strict Scottish boarding school (referred to by some, says Stonborough, as “Colditz in a kilt”) where Charles’s father sent him to “toughen him up.” Not only did Charles not make many friends there, but he also endured bullying from upperclassmen under approval from the headmaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The Curious Conservative Case Against Defending Ukraine
description: George Orwell would have called it objectively pro-Putin.
content: One of the stranger features of the politics of the war in Ukraine is that the most vocal opposition to it tends to come from the hard right. In some ways, that right sounds like the hard left it used to oppose so fiercely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hermione Hoby
title: A Novel Depicts One Disordered Night in the Life of a Teenager
description: “Shy,” by Max Porter, offers a look inside the multidimensional consciousness of a troubled young man.
content: Shuffling out into a damp, black English night toward a muddy pond in the year 1995, a kid bears the weight of the world on his shoulders. That, plus a real rucksack stuffed with flint rocks. This is Shy, a drum-and-bass-obsessed boy with behavioral problems, and a protagonist in whom myth and bathos slyly collide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The ‘Woke Mind Virus’ Is Eating Away at Republicans’ Brains
description: President Biden is the primary beneficiary of the G.O.P.’s deepening radicalism.
content: There are a few reasons to think that President Biden might lose his bid for re-election next year, even if Donald Trump is once more — for the third straight time — the Republican nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen
title: Does America Realize That Sudan Is Too Big to Fail?
description: The people of Sudan have been all but abandoned in the crossfire of a fight to the death between the two men who want to rule them.
content: Two heavily armed groups, led by sworn enemies, square off in a dense metropolitan area that is home to about as many people as New York City. Hundreds of civilians have died, and thousands have been wounded, though the true toll may be much higher. People are pinned down in their homes by street-to-street fighting and aerial bombardment. They are running out of food and water; hospitals are running out of supplies. International humanitarian workers have packed up their white sport utility vehicles and high-tailed it to safety. Western and regional diplomats have boarded helicopters, buses and planes to get out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: We Are Opening the Lids on Two Giant Pandora’s Boxes
description: Social media illustrated some of the perils of unchecked technology.
content: Merriam-Webster notes that a “Pandora’s box” can be “anything that looks ordinary but may produce unpredictable harmful results.” I’ve been thinking a lot about Pandora’s boxes lately, because we Homo sapiens are doing something we’ve never done before: lifting the lids on two giant Pandora’s boxes at the same time, without any idea of what could come flying out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Shannon Lin, Rikki Novetsky, Lisa Chow, MJ Davis Lin, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
title: A Third Bank Implodes. Now What?
description: The seizing of First Republic by regulators could signal the end of the banking crisis.
content: On Monday morning, the federal government took over a third failing bank — this time, First Republic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: California College Town Rocked by Stabbings That Remain a Mystery
description: Two people have died and a third person has been wounded over the course of five days in Davis, Calif. The police said they were uncertain whether only one assailant was involved.
content: A placid Northern California college town has been rocked by a series of stabbings in which two people have been killed and a third critically wounded in less than a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Restaurant Review: Naro Makes New Magic From Classic Korean Dishes
description: In a sleek, futuristic Rockefeller Center space, the owners of Atomix and Atoboy reach back in time to traditional recipes.
content: At their groundbreaking restaurant Atomix, Junghyun and Jeongeun Park seem to have the keys to a secret room filled with flavors that New York’s older Korean restaurants barely hint at. Nearly every course on the elaborate tasting menus is made up of a dozen or more ingredients. There are stunning imported vinegars derived from mugwort, birch and cherry blossoms. Kimchi, often made on site, does not stop with cabbage and radishes but plunges into a realm of fermented tomatoes, chiles and mustard leaves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Authentic Social Media?
description: Which social media apps do you use? Is it possible to truly be real on any of them?
content: “BeReal was pitched as Gen Z’s safe haven from the artifice of social media. For some, authenticity only proved interesting for so long,” a recent Times article reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Tannenbaum
title: Gordon Lightfoot’s 10 Essential Songs
description: The Canadian singer-songwriter, who died on Monday at 84, brought his rueful baritone to memorable, melancholy material.
content: Bob Dylan once named Gordon Lightfoot one of his favorite songwriters, and called the musician “somebody of rare talent” while inducting him into the Canadian Music Hall of Fame in 1986. On Dylan’s 1970 album “Self Portrait,” he even recorded Lightfoot’s “Early Morning Rain,” and the respect was mutual — Lightfoot listened carefully to Dylan’s songs, which instilled in him “a more direct approach, getting away from the love songs,” he once said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja and Andrew Das
title: FIFA Threatens Women’s World Cup TV Blackout in Europe
description: Gianni Infantino said matches would not be shown in the continent’s biggest markets this summer unless broadcasters meet FIFA’s demands for higher fees.
content: The president of soccer’s global governing body on Tuesday harshly criticized European broadcasters for not meeting FIFA’s demands for significantly higher television rights fees for this summer’s Women’s World Cup in Australia and New Zealand. If the offers did not improve, he threatened, the tournament’s matches would not be televised in many of Europe’s biggest markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: The Culture Creating A.I. Is Weird. Here’s Why That Matters.
description: Erik Davis discusses the “high weirdness” that has shaped California and the development of A.I.
content: In recent months, we’ve witnessed the rise of chatbots that can pass law and business school exams, artificial companions who’ve become best friends and lovers and music generators that produce remarkably humanlike songs. It’s hard to know how to process it all. But if there’s one thing that’s certain, it’s this: The future — shaped by technologies like artificial intelligence — is going to be profoundly weird. In look, feel and function, it will be different from the world we have grown to recognize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James R. Oestreich
title: Illuminating Rachmaninoff’s Vespers, a Pinnacle of Russian Sacred Rep
description: Steven Fox and the Clarion Choir are tending to a less well-known part of the composer’s canon for his 150th birthday: His choral works.
content: In a classical music world obsessed with anniversaries, be they grand or modest, the 150th birthday of the Russian émigré composer Sergei Rachmaninoff has inevitably drawn notice. Just as inevitably, commemorations have tended to focus on his war horses: the symphonies, piano concertos and solo piano works.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Will Decide Next Rate Move After Bank Jitters
description: The Federal Reserve will release a policy decision on Wednesday on the heels of another bank collapse.
content: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials are widely expected to lift borrowing costs by a quarter of a percentage point on Wednesday, the 10th consecutive rate increase since March 2022. But investors and economists think that this could be the central bank’s last move before it pauses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman and Gabe Cohn
title: Tony Awards Nominations 2023: The Complete List
description: Nominations for the 76th Tony Awards were announced Tuesday morning. Here’s who made the list.
content: Nominations for the 2023 Tony Awards were announced Tuesday by the actress Lea Michele, who is currently in “Funny Girl” on Broadway, and Myles Frost, who won a 2022 Tony Award for his portrayal of Michael Jackson in the Broadway musical “MJ.” Some categories were read live on CBS at 8:30 a.m. Eastern; others were unveiled through a livestream on the Tony Awards YouTube page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: A Minimalist Australian Dream Home With an 18th-Century Twist
description: Why would a modernist house in a Melbourne suburb need an inverted ha-ha? (And what is a ha-ha, anyway?)
content: As the real estate market in Melbourne, Australia, sizzled and home prices surged in 2017, Chris Calleja and Joy Suemag were scrambling to find a larger house for their young family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Solomon
title: Abraham Verghese’s Sweeping New Fable of Family and Medicine
description: “The Covenant of Water” follows three generations of a close-knit and haunted family in southwestern India.
content: Abraham Verghese occupies a curious place in the modern literary landscape. A doctor who decided midcareer to train at the Iowa Writers’ Workshop, he has gone on to achieve distinction in both fields. He is a professor of the theory and practice of medicine at Stanford Medical School, continues in clinical practice, has won the National Humanities Medal, speaks widely about the importance of the human element of what has become a technocratic practice, and has won awards for both fiction and nonfiction. His last novel, “Cutting for Stone,” spent more than two years on this newspaper’s best-seller list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: How JPMorgan Became Banking’s Regular Rescuer
description: The largest bank is also the only one whose stability hasn’t been questioned. Its C.E.O. makes sure of that.
content: It was well before dawn on Monday when federal regulators notified JPMorgan Chase executives that they had beaten out three smaller rivals in their bid to buy the doomed First Republic Bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: As Broadway Rebounds, ‘Some Like It Hot’ Gets 13 Tony Nominations
description: The musicals “New York, New York,” “Shucked” and “& Juliet” each got nine and “Kimberly Akimbo” picked up eight. Several major stars earned nominations.
content: As Broadway’s rebound from the pandemic shutdown picks up pace, Tony nominators showered much-sought attention on a wide variety of shows, from razzle-dazzle spectacles to quirky adventurous fare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Seth Meyers Contemplates the 2024 Presidential Matchup
description: Meyers said a Biden-versus-Trump rematch would be “like a book club you feel obligated to attend.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford Reports $1.8 Billion Profit in Quarter
description: Sales increased from a year earlier, when the automaker was hampered by parts shortages.
content: Ford Motor reported a solid profit in the first quarter, although the automaker indicated that its turnaround was not complete and that it had a ways to go before it starts making money on electric vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Wallis
title: An Aggressive Passive Push for a Brooklyn Brownstone
description: Updating a Victorian brownstone in Carroll Gardens according to Passive House principles didn’t mean sacrificing the charm.
content: When Hope Reeves and Martin Walker bought an 1899 brownstone in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, five years ago, they knew it was going to require a lot of work to meet their ambitions for a smartly functional and stylish home to share with their three sons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: A Drone Opera, Brought to You by General Dynamics? A Company Clarifies.
description: “Grounded,” a new work about the psychological toll of drone warfare, drew scrutiny after its presenter, Washington National Opera, advertised the support of a major military contractor.
content: When the Washington National Opera announced that it would open its coming season with the premiere of “Grounded,” a new opera exploring the psychological toll of drone warfare, its star composer, Jeanine Tesori, got less attention than its listed sponsor: General Dynamics, the military contractor.
source.name: The New York Times

description: See full results and maps from the Alabama primary elections.
content: See full results and maps from the Alabama primary elections.

description: See full results and maps from the Minnesota primary elections.
content: See full results and maps from the Minnesota primary elections.

content: See full results and maps from the Alabama primary elections.

title: Met Gala 2023: Best Looks
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: How Do We Ensure an A.I. Future That Allows for Human Thriving?
description: A.I. entrepreneur Gary Marcus thinks the technology is too important to cede to corporate control.
content: A.I. entrepreneur Gary Marcus thinks the technology is too important to cede to corporate control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mira Rojanasakul and Max Bearak
title: Is It a Lake, or a Battery? A New Kind of Hydropower Is Spreading Fast.
description: So-called pumped storage, rather than conventional dams, is emerging as the future of deriving electricity from water's gravitational qualities.
content: So-called pumped storage, rather than conventional dams, is emerging as the future of deriving electricity from water's gravitational qualities.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Modern Australian Oasis Just Outside Melbourne
description: Why would a modernist suburban house need an inverted ha-ha? (And what is a ha-ha, anyway?)
content: Why would a modernist suburban house need an inverted ha-ha? (And what is a ha-ha, anyway?)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: ‘No Contracts, No Scripts,’ Hollywood Writers Begin Strike
description: Television and screenwriters picketed outside Netflix’s office building in Los Angeles and on the streets of New York City.
content: Television and screenwriters picketed outside Netflix’s office building in Los Angeles and on the streets of New York City.
source.name: The New York Times
